candidates.title: Use the new feature resolver
candidates.body:
# Previous  behaviour

The usage of an optional feature always pulls the optional dependencies listed in the same feature even if these dependencies weren't explicitly required, which is generally undesired, surprising and slower.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `with-serde` will always bring `serde` as well as `rgb`
with-serde = ["rgb/serde", "serde"]
```

# Current behaviour

With the new "weak dependency" feature, optional dependencies won't be automatically pulled effectively solving the above problem.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `rgb` won't be included unless the `rgb` feature is required
with-serde = ["rgb?/serde", "serde"]
```

# Future behaviour

The "name-spaced dependency" feature enables the listing of optional features using the name of any optional dependency, so, instead of creating features with prefixes, suffices or funny names to avoid overlapping, it will be possible to group related stuff in intuitive names.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `serde` can now be used as a feature with `dep:`
serde = ["rgb?/serde", "dep:serde"]
```

candidates.title: Bump Diesel 2 feature support
candidates.body: Diesel 2.0 is released so bumping `rc` support for major version support.

candidates.title: Version 1.26.1
candidates.body: A hotfix release which doesn't meaningfully change behavior of the features but resolves documentation related issues.

candidates.title: Diesel 2 feature support
candidates.body:
This enables `diesel 2.0.0-rc.1` support via two new feature flags: `db-diesel2-mysql` and `db-diesel2-postgres`. In fact, to make things easier `diesel` features are now explicit (i.e. `db-diesel1-*`) with a backwards compatible feature flag pointing to version `1.4`.

Another notable change is that because of uncertainty building both `diesel1` and `diesel2` at the same time, I explicitly include a compiler error if both features are enabled. 

Subsequently, the build system needed to relax during the first build step. It built using `--all-features` however due to complexities with Serde configuration etc it was admittedly a little pointless. Sadly though, I can't use `--all-features` on `clippy` anymore - though as a future change I made move this to the makefile and process feature by feature. It'd be nice if `cargo` allowed you to _exclude_ features as that way we could avoid conflicting features. 

Anyway, this closes #531 and replaces #512 (though thank you for the quick and easy updates I could apply!)

candidates.title: add rkyv support
candidates.body: This PR add optional rkyv support for Decimal.

candidates.title: Add `rand` support
candidates.body:
Fix https://github.com/paupino/rust-decimal/issues/489 (Don't know why the issue was closed)

Through a feature called `rand` that is disabled by default

candidates.title: Remove unused dependencies
candidates.body:
Reduces network usage and decreases compilation times for development environments

`cargo test --all-features` went down from 330 to 324.

candidates.title: Update to Rust 2021
candidates.body:
Perhaps the most useful thing about 2021 is the inclusion of TryFrom/TryInto in the prelude or perhaps the ability of calling `into_iter` on arrays.

Feel free to close this PR if the changes are not worth including.

candidates.title: Fixes issue with workspace build always including default
candidates.body: This resolves an issue with `no_std` tests not actually executing under the right context due to the workspace build automatically resolving and including the `default` feature.

candidates.title: Minor description changes to help with discoverability
Version sync tests for ensuring documentation up to date
Borsh Support
candidates.body:
Adding support for Borsh serialization via an optional crate feature.
I've only added this to the Decimal object so far, please let me know where else to add this needs to be supported.

candidates.title: parse_str_exact implementation, utilized by macro parsing
candidates.body:
`parse_str_exact` function to generate an error on underflow instead of automatically rounding. Fixes #411.

Also utilizes this function in the macros to provide better error messages.

candidates.title: Version 1.21
candidates.body: Includes a bit of a documentation clean up with further examples added. I'm opting to start using `dec!` in doc examples too, however that can be rolled out slowly. The downside is the extra import line each time - I wonder if there is a way to import for all doc tests?

candidates.title: Exercise `Decimal::deserialize`
candidates.body: I guess this is the last fallible `Decimal` constructor

candidates.title: Add MySQL support for Diesel
candidates.body:
Fixes #439 

Unfortunately, the spec for the `decimal` protocol in MySQL isn't complete: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/internals/en/binary-protocol-value.html#packet-ProtocolBinary::MYSQL_TYPE_DECIMAL

Reverse engineering some other libraries, including official connectors, it appears that it simply uses a binary string format for decimals.

candidates.title: Add support for Rocket forms
candidates.body:
Hello!

Here's a simple implementation for [Rocket](https://rocket.rs)'s [`FromFormField`](https://api.rocket.rs/v0.5-rc/rocket/form/trait.FromFormField.html).

This allows reading `Decimal`s straight from web form fields (either bodies or query strings).

I'm not sure if the feature name is good enough, but i couldn't think of any other. I've also added a test. Should i add a failing one as well?

candidates.title: Remove unecessary arrayvec feature
candidates.body: `rust-decimal` does not use any features provided by the `std` flag of `arrayvec`, therefore, unnecessary .

candidates.title: Add benchmarks to compare different structures
candidates.body:
Only compares floating primitives with arithmetic operations using equal and different left and right hand values.

![add](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/130302200-cb1ea1cb-c048-4eb6-a867-4978bfbffbf1.jpg)
![div](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/130302259-90c3bb46-8f6a-4f31-bd6b-6fcce6fc2e4c.jpg)

Quite interesting results

candidates.title: Add benchmarks to compare different structures
candidates.body:
Useful to see how `rust-decimal` is performing compared to other libraries or how much is lagging behind `f32` or `f64` hardware based operations.

![addition](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458061-82c68e19-3cf0-48a2-be0d-a1c70ed7ab46.jpg)
![division](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458091-cf613144-bdbc-47dc-9848-4ec4bbf719d4.jpg)
![subtration](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458100-b938c42e-47da-4036-9b5c-75c0ca2209cd.jpg)
![multiplication](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458110-a9ec31a1-fa48-4730-b835-d829bf3cbd27.jpg)

As seen from above, `rust-decimal` is the fastest decimal library with operations ~2000% slower if compared to native primitives.

candidates.title: Version/1.15
candidates.body:
Fixes #395.
Fixes #380.

candidates.title: log 10 implementation
candidates.body:
Implements `log10` as well as `checked_` functions for `ln` and `log10`. To maintain backwards compatibility in regards to "no panics" a feature `maths-nopanic` has been introduced. While it's not truly backwards compatible, it does allow for previous behavior to be re-instated. Closes #397.

This also introduces a number of constants since a few were required for the `ln` algorithm. Fixes #400.

candidates.title: fix panic in call to Decimal::ZERO.ln()
candidates.body:
Fixes https://github.com/paupino/rust-decimal/issues/398

I wasn't sure whether to write the `VERSION.md` update myself or not - of course feel free to update the language as you see fit.
